Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.

A subgroup H of a finite group G is called a p-Sylow subgroup if H is a p-group such that p does not divide the index (G: H). This means there exist integers k, m in N satisfying ord H=p^k, as well as ord G=p^k m, where p does not divide m.
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.

A permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$ is called a cycle if there exist distinct elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}$ in $\{1, \ldots, n\}, r \geq 2$, such that $\pi(x_{i}) = x_{i+1}$ for $1 \leq i < r$, $\pi(x_{r}) = x_{1}$, and $\pi(x) = x$ for $x \in \{1, \ldots, n\} - \{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$.
A cycle involving $r$ elements is called an $r$-cycle and is denoted as $\pi = (x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$.
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Sign or Signature of a Permutation

The sign or signature of a permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$, denoted as $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$, is defined by the product $\prod_{i<j} \frac{\pi(i)-\pi(j)}{i-j}$. The sign can only assume the values 1 and -1. If $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$ is positive, $\pi$ is called an even permutation, and an odd permutation otherwise.

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.

The Klein four-group, denoted as $\mathfrak{V}_{4}$, is a subgroup of $\mathfrak{S}_{4}$ consisting of the permutations $\{\mathrm{id}, (1,2)(3,4), (1,3)(2,4), (1,4)(2,3)\}$. It is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$.
An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A cycle is a specific type of permutation within the symmetric group, thus it is a specialization of the symmetric group.
An r-cycle is a cycle involving exactly r elements, making it a specialization of the general concept of a cycle.
A transposition is a 2-cycle, which is a specific type of cycle, thus it is a specialization of the cycle.
The alternating group consists of all even permutations in the symmetric group, making it a specialization of the symmetric group.
The dihedral group is generated by specific permutations within the symmetric group, making it a specialization of the symmetric group.
The Klein four-group is a subgroup of the symmetric group on four elements, making it a specialization of the symmetric group.
